Author: mvs2527

Comment: No, it won't. You're not understanding what happened. Our court in WI is 4-3 liberal. Suspend in a legal context is not a punishment. It literally says in the article it's an administrative decision, not disciplinary.   >Court officials emphasized that this is not a disciplinary action but an administrative one.  Any defendant that showed up in her court and had a guilty verdict could appeal based her current legal status. It's in both hers and the public's best interest that her cases are currently reassigned to another judge, and in order to do that, she needs to be suspended.   It maintains the integrity of the entire judicial system to suspend a judge facing a legal proceeding. I'd much rather have them suspend her with the precedence they'd suspend any judge facing a legal proceeding, than not suspending her and allowing precedence to leave an actual corrupt judge facing a legal proceeding on the bench.   If the charges are dismissed, she would be back on the bench immediately. Again, this is administrative. It has no disciplinary effect or goes on a record of any kind.
Author: undercurrents

Comment: The suspension is correct, and nobody should see her suspension as an acknowledgment that the charges have any merit. It's unreasonable to expect her to perform her duties as a judge while facing criminal charges, even if those charges are bogus. Suspension is probably standard policy when a judge is charged, and for good reason.

Author: PeakOk3826

Comment: The chilling behavior is that of ICE. Not the Supreme Court who is not playing favorites by suspending a judge facing legal proceedings, and whose cases could end up getting appealed and overturned.   The Supreme Court is NOT making a ruling on her innocence or guilt. It's upholding the integrity of the court by temporarily suspending a judge from presiding over cases that could later be challenged. And once again, if you don't want an actual criminal or corrupt judge still sitting on the bench while awaiting criminal proceedings in the future, you apply the same rule to all.   What the Supreme Court is doing is correct. They are not weighing in on her guilt or innocence. A judge is facing legal proceedings- they are temporarily removing cases from their docket til it's resolved.
Author: undercurrents

Comment: You're reading an attribution of blame on the Supreme Court when that's not been necessarily implied. The ordeal she is going through, including the suspension, will have a chilling effect. The Supreme Court didn't cause that situation, and I don't see anybody you are replying to suggest that they did. The suggestion is only that the fact that she has to go through this will have a chilling effect on other judges.. which it will, as is the intent.
